snippet: The Ruthvens, the Satterlees, the Spillers and the Halsteads, among many families now presumed dead after the landslide in Oso, Wash., defined their neighborhood with their lives.
abstract: Houses on Steelhead Drive in Oso, Wash, bore the surging brunt of the landslide that destroyed 49 homes and has left 28 dead and 20 others still missing; Steelhead Drive is a name that seems to epitomize the extent of the devastation, as it seems to be repeated again and again like the chorus of a dirge.

byline.original: By KIRK JOHNSON, JACK HEALY and IAN LOVETT
byline.contributor: Kirk Johnson reported from Oso, Jack Healy from Denver, and Ian Lovett from Los Angeles. Alain Delaquérière contributed reporting from New York.

lead_paragraph: The Ruthvens, the Satterlees, the Spillers and the Halsteads, among many families now presumed dead after the landslide in Oso, Wash., defined their neighborhood with their lives.

headline.main: Steelhead Drive Is Gone After Mudslide, Along With Many Lives Lived on It
headline.print_headline: Steelhead Drive Is Gone, Along With So Many Lives Lived on It
